item.title: Palestinian Doctors Can Drive Own Vehicles Into Israel, Agency Says
item.description: The decision, exempting dozens of doctors from a blanket ban in force for 15 years, is the latest in a series of steps to relax constraints on Palestinians entering Israel.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: World Briefing: Philippines: Rebel Leader Is Dead
item.description: Ameril Umbra Kato organized the Bangsamoro Islamic Freedom Fighters to battle for an independent Islamic state.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Draghi Is Expected to Recommit E.C.B. to Bond-Buying Program
item.description: A survey published by the European Central Bank showed that lending is increasing in the eurozone after years of tight credit.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING

item.title: World Briefing: Egypt: Barring of Gay Man Upheld
item.description: The student, who was not identified, had appealed the decision, hoping to resume his studies in Alexandria.
item.category: Arab Academy for Science, Technology and Maritime Transport
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Italy: 400 May Have Drowned in Capsizing of Migrant Ship
item.description: Based on its interviews of survivors who arrived in Reggio Calabria in southern Italy, Save the Children said that 400 people may have drowned.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Brazil: Eviction of Squatters Turns Chaotic Amid Olympic Tensions
item.description: Though the squatters had agreed to leave, when police officers in riot gear charged in, pandemonium erupted and squatters set two fires.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Sierra Leone: Schools Reopen as Ebola Outbreak Subsides
item.description: More than 8,000 schools were reopening, although attendance at many was poor amid some skepticism that the crisis was over.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Blackwater’s Legacy Goes Beyond Public View
item.description: Private security firms have matured from bit players on the edge of global conflicts to multinational companies that guard oil fields, analyze intelligence and fight insurgents.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: JAMES RISEN and MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: Erik Prince, left, founder of the private military company Xe, formerly Blackwater Worldwide, travels by helicopter to an Xe base near the Afghan-Pakistan border for a routine visit, in Kabul, Afghanistan on Sept. 24, 2009.

item.title: Eduardo Galeano, Uruguayan Voice of Anti-Capitalism, Is Dead at 74
item.description: Mr. Galeano was a Uruguayan writer who blended literature, journalism and political satire in reflecting on the vagaries, injustices and small victories of history.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO
item.media:description: Eduardo Galeano, after a speech at the National Pedagogical University in Tegucigalpa, Honduras, in 2005.

item.title: U.S. Drone Kills a Top Figure in Al Qaeda’s Yemen Branch
item.description: The drone strike killed Ibrahim al-Rubeish, an ideologue and spokesman for Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula who had been a prisoner at Guantánamo Bay.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: SCOTT SHANE
item.media:credit: U.S. State Department Rewards For Justice, via Associated Press

item.title: Obama Yields, Allowing Congress Say on Iran Nuclear Deal
item.description: President Obama would sign a compromise bill giving Congress a voice on the proposed nuclear accord as the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, in rare unanimity, moved the legislation to the full Senate for a vote.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN WEISMAN and PETER BAKER
item.media:description: Mr. Kerry left a classified briefing with senators at the Capitol.

item.title: Obama Gives Visiting Iraqi Premier Aid and an Endorsement
item.description: Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi left the White House on Tuesday still in need of billions more dollars to cope with plunging oil prices and a yawning budget deficit.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: U.S. Soldiers, Back in Iraq, Find Security Forces in Disrepair
item.description: American troops returning for the first time since 2011 said they were stunned by the state of the army they had once trained.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: American trainers spoke with Iraqi Army recruits at a military base on Sunday in Taji, Iraq.

item.title: U.N.’s Syria Envoy Looks to Revive Talks
item.description: Staffan de Mistura will hold individual meetings with representatives of the warring parties and the countries that support them. It is not known if Iran, perhaps the top supporter of Syria’s government, will be involved.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Chimps That Hunt Offer a New View on Evolution
item.description: While males catch their prey, mostly by chasing it down, the females use broken tree branches to jab theirs and are much more avid tool users than the males, a 10-year study found.
item.dc:creator: JAMES GORMAN
item.media:description: An adult male chimpanzee in Senegal, left, uses a tree branch with a modified end to stab into a tree cavity in a video image from the TV show "Life Story." A 10-year study found that females in Senegal play an unexpectedly big role in hunting.

item.title: Looking Back at the Holocaust, Through a Child’s Eyes
item.description: A new exhibit in Jerusalem collects memories, toys and drawings from children who survived and from some of the many who did not.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Children look at dolls that are on display at Yad Vashem, the Holocaust memorial museum in Jerusalem.

item.title: Open Source: Anticorruption Activist in Russia Sentenced for Street Art ‘Theft’
item.description: A court in Russia convicted a colleague of the opposition leader Aleksei Navalny of theft for removing street art from a wall in a provincial city.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Lecce Journal: Centuries of Italian History Are Unearthed in Quest to Fix Toilet
item.description: As he tried to find a sewage pipe, Luciano Faggiano dug his way past a Messapian tomb, a Roman granary, a Franciscan chapel and even etchings from the Knights Templar.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY
item.media:credit: Davide Monteleone for The New York Times
item.media:description: Luciano Faggiano, center right, with his sons in what is now the Museum Faggiano. Mr. Faggiano had originally planned to run a trattoria in the structure, but discovered a trove of archaeological treasures while trying to fix a sewage pipe.

item.title: Jason Rezaian, Washington Post Reporter Imprisoned in Tehran, Is Subjected to ‘Kafkaesque Restrictions,’ Editor Says
item.description: The newspaper’s executive editor said the restrictions include only one hour of pretrial time with a defense lawyer for the reporter, Jason Rezaian, imprisoned for nearly nine months.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Günter Grass’s Germany, and Mine
item.description: Why the man called our ‘national conscience’ never appealed to me.
item.dc:creator: JOCHEN BITTNER
